cleaned_text: and Roman medicine In the following century the work of [Aristotle](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Aristotle), regarded as the first great biologist, was of inestimable value to medicine. A pupil of [Plato](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Plato) at Athens and tutor to [Alexander the Great](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Alexander-the-Great), Aristotle studied the entire world of living things. He laid what can be identified as the foundations of [comparative anatomy](https://www.britannica.com/science/comparative-anatomy) and [embryology](https://www.britannica.com/science/embryology), and his views influenced scientific thinking for the next 2,000 years. After the time of Aristotle, the centre of Greek [culture](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/culture) shifted to [Alexandria](https://www.britannica.com/place/Alexandria-Egypt), where a famous medical school was established about 300 bce. There the two best medical teachers were [Herophilus](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Herophilus), whose [treatise](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/treatise) on anatomy may have been the first of its kind, and [Erasistratus](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Erasistratus-of-Ceos), regarded by some as the founder of physiology. Erasistratus noted the difference between sensory and motor nerves but thought that the nerves were hollow tubes containing fluid and that air entered the [lungs](https://www.britannica.com/science/lung) and [heart](https://www.britannica.com/science/heart) and was carried through the body in the [arteries](https://www.britannica.com/science/artery). Alexandria continued as a centre of medical teaching even after the Roman Empire had attained supremacy over the Greek world, and medical knowledge remained predominantly Greek. [Asclepiades of Bithynia](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Asclepiades-of-Bithynia) (born 124 bce) differed from Hippocrates in that he denied the healing power of nature and insisted that disease should be treated safely, speedily, and agreeably. An opponent of the humoral theory, he drew upon the [atomic theory](https://www.britannica.com/science/atomic-theory) of 5th-century Greek philosopher [Democritus](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Democritus) in advocating a doctrine of strictum et laxum—the [attribution](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/attribution) of disease to the contracted or relaxed condition of the solid particles that he believed make up the body. To restore harmony among the particles and thus effect cures, Asclepiades used typically Greek remedies: massage, poultices, occasional tonics, fresh air, and corrective diet. He gave particular attention to [mental](https://www.britannica.com/science/mental-hygiene) disease, clearly distinguishing hallucinations from [delusions](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/delusions). He released the insane from confinement in dark cellars and prescribed a [regimen](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/regimen) of [occupational therapy](https://www.britannica.com/science/occupational-therapy), soothing music, soporifics (especially wine), and exercises to improve the [attention](https://www.britannica.com/science/attention) and [memory](https://www.britannica.com/science/memory-psychology). Asclepiades did much to win acceptance for Greek medicine in Rome. [Aulus Cornelius Celsus](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Aulus-Cornelius-Celsus), the Roman nobleman who wrote De medicina about 30 ce, gave a classic account of Greek medicine of the time, including descriptions of elaborate surgical operations. His book, overlooked in his day, enjoyed a wide reputation during the [Renaissance](https://www.britannica.com/event/Renaissance). During the early centuries of the Christian era, Greek doctors thronged to [Rome](https://www.britannica.com/place/ancient-Rome). The most [illustrious](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/illustrious) of them was [Galen](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Galen), who began practicing there in 161 ce. He acknowledged his debt to Hippocrates and followed the Hippocratic method, accepting the doctrine of the humours. He laid stress on the value of anatomy, and he virtually founded experimental physiology. Galen recognized that the arteries contain blood and not merely air. He showed how the heart sets the blood in motion in an ebb and flow fashion, but he had no idea that the blood circulates. Dissection of the [human body](https://www.britannica.com/science/human-body) was at that time illegal, so that he was forced to base his knowledge upon the examination of animals, particularly [apes](https://www.britannica.com/animal/ape). A [voluminous](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/voluminous) writer who stated his views forcibly and with confidence, he remained for centuries the undisputed authority from whom no one dared to differ. Another influential physician of the 2nd century ce was [Soranus of Ephesus](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Soranus-of-Ephesus), who wrote authoritatively on childbirth, infant care, and women's diseases. An opponent of [abortion](https://www.britannica.com/science/abortion-pregnancy), he advocated numerous means of [contraception](https://www.britannica.com/topic/contraception). He also described how to assist a difficult delivery by turning the [fetus](https://www.britannica.com/science/fetus) in the uterus (podalic version), a life-saving technique that was subsequently lost sight of until it was revived in the 16th century. Although the contribution of Rome to the practice of medicine was negligible compared with that of Greece, in matters of [public health](https://www.britannica.com/topic/public-health) the Romans set the world a great example. The city of Rome had an unrivaled [water supply](https://www.britannica.com/science/water-supply). Gymnasiums and public baths were provided, and there was even domestic sanitation and adequate disposal of sewage. The army had its medical officers, public physicians were appointed to attend the poor, and hospitals were built; a Roman [hospital](https://www.britannica.com/science/hospital) excavated near Düsseldorf, Germany, was found to be strikingly modern in design. [Christian](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Christianity) and [Muslim](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Islamic-world) reservoirs of learning After the fall of Rome, learning was no longer held in high esteem, experiment was discouraged, and originality became a dangerous asset. During the early [Middle Ages](https://www.britannica.com/event/Middle-Ages) medicine passed into the widely [diverse](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/diverse) hands of the Christian church and Arab scholars. Translators and saints It is sometimes stated that the [early Christian church](https://www.britannica.com/topic/history-of-early-Christianity) had an adverse effect upon medical progress. Disease was regarded as a punishment for sin, and such chastening demanded only prayer and repentance. Moreover, the human body was held sacred and dissection was forbidden. But the [infinite](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/infinite) care and [nursing](https://www.britannica.com/science/nursing) bestowed upon the sick under Christian [auspices](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/auspices) must outweigh any intolerance shown toward medicine in the early days. Perhaps the greatest service rendered to medicine by the church was the preservation and transcription of the Classical Greek medical manuscripts. These were translated into Latin in many [medieval](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/medieval) monasteries, and the [Nestorian](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Nestorianism) Christians (an Eastern church) established a school of translators to render the Greek texts into Arabic. This famous school, and also a great hospital, were located at Jundi Shhpr in southwest Persia, where the chief physician was Jurjs ibn Bukhtsh, the first of a [dynasty](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dynasty) of translators and physicians that lasted for six generations. A later translator of great renown was [unayn ibn Isq](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Hunayn-ibn-Ishaq), or Johannitus (born 809), whose translations were said to be worth their weight in gold. About this time there appeared a number of [saints](https://www.britannica.com/topic/saint) whose names were associated with miraculous cures. Among the earliest of these were twin brothers, [Cosmas and Damian](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Saint-Cosmas), who suffered martyrdom (c. 303) and became the [patron saints](https://www.britannica.com/topic/patron-saint) of medicine. Other saints were [invoked](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/invoked) as powerful healers of certain diseases, such as St. Vitus for [chorea](https://www.britannica.com/science/chorea-human-disease) (or St. Vitus's dance) and St. Anthony for [erysipelas](https://www.britannica.com/science/erysipelas) (or St. Anthony's fire). The cult of these saints was widespread in medieval times, and a later cult, that of St. Roch for plague, was widespread during the plague-ridden years of the 14th century. Arabian medicine A second reservoir of medical learning during those times was the great [Muslim empire](https://www.britannica.com/place/Caliphate), which extended from Persia to Spain. Although it is customary to speak of [Arabian medicine](https://www.britannica.com/science/Unani-medicine) in describing this period, not all of the physicians were Arabs or natives of Arabia. Nor, indeed, were they all Muslims: some were Jews, some Christians, and they were drawn from all parts of the empire. One of the earliest figures was [Rhazes](https://www.britannica.com/biography/al-Razi), a [Persian](https://www.britannica.com/place/Iran) born in the last half of the 9th century near modern Tehrn, who wrote a voluminous treatise on medicine, Kitb al-h (" [Comprehensive Book](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kitab-al-hawi)"), but whose most famous work, De variolis et morbillis (A Treatise on the Smallpox and Measles), distinguishes between these two diseases and gives a clear description of both. Of later date was [Avicenna](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Avicenna) (980-1037), a Muslim physician, who has been called the prince of physicians and whose tomb at Hamadan has become a place of pilgrimage. He could repeat the [Qurn](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Quran) before he was 10 years old and at the age of 18 became court physician. His principal medical work, Al-Qnn f a-ibb ( [The Canon of Medicine](https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Canon-of-Medicine)), became a classic and was used at many medical schools—at Montpellier, France, as late as 1650—and reputedly is still used in the East. The greatest contribution of Arabian medicine was in [chemistry](https://www.britannica.com/science/chemistry) and in the knowledge and preparation of medicines. The chemists of that time were alchemists, and their pursuit was mainly a search for the [philosopher's stone](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophers-stone), which supposedly would turn common metals into gold. In the course of their experiments, however, numerous substances were named and characterized, and some were found to have medicinal value. Many drugs are of Arab origin, as are such processes as [sublimation](https://www.britannica.com/science/sublimation-phase-change). In that period, and indeed throughout most historical times, [surgery](https://www.britannica.com/science/surgery-medicine) was considered inferior to medicine, and surgeons were held in low regard. Renowned Spanish surgeon [Ab al-Qsim](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Abu-al-Qasim) (Albucasis), however, did much to raise the status of surgery in [Córdoba](https://www.britannica.com/place/Cordoba-Spain), an important centre of commerce and culture with a hospital and medical school equal to those of Cairo and Baghdad. A careful and [conservative](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/conservative) practitioner, he wrote the first illustrated surgical text, which held wide influence in Europe for centuries. Another great doctor of Córdoba, born in the 12th century, just as the sun of Arabian culture was setting, was Jewish philosopher [Moses Maimonides](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Moses-Maimonides). Banished from the city because he would not become a Muslim, he eventually went to Cairo, where the law was more [lenient](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/lenient) and where he acquired a reputation so high that he became physician to [Saladin](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Saladin), the Saracen leader. (He was the original of El Hakim in [Sir Walter Scott](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Walter-Scott)'s Talisman.) A few of his works, written in Hebrew, were eventually translated into Latin and printed. Medieval and Renaissance Europe [Salerno](https://www.britannica.com/topic/University-of-Salerno) and the medical schools At about the same time that Arabian medicine flourished, the first organized medical school in Europe was established at Salerno, in southern Italy. Although the school of Salerno produced no brilliant genius and no startling discovery, it was the outstanding medical institution of its time and the parent of the great medieval schools soon to be founded at Montpellier and Paris, in France, and at Bologna and Padua, in Italy. Salerno drew scholars from near and far. Remarkably liberal in some of its views, Salerno admitted women as medical students. The school owed much to the [enlightened](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/enlightened) [Holy Roman emperor](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Holy-Roman-emperor) [Frederick II](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Frederick-II-Holy-Roman-emperor), who decreed in 1221 that no one should practice medicine until he had been publicly approved by the masters of Salerno. The Salernitan school also produced a literature of its own. The best-known work, of uncertain date and of composite authorship, was the Regimen Sanitatis Salernitanum ("Salernitan Guide to Health"). Written in verse, it appeared in numerous editions and was translated into many languages. Among its oft-quoted couplets is the following: Use three physicians still, first Doctor Quiet, Next Doctor Merryman, and Doctor Diet. Salerno yielded its place as the premier medical school of Europe to [Montpellier](https://www.britannica.com/place/Montpellier) about 1200. John of Gaddesden, the model for the "doctour of physick" in [Geoffrey Chaucer's](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Geoffrey-Chaucer) [Canterbury Tales](https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Canterbury-Tales), was one of the English students there. That he relied upon astrology and upon the doctrine of the humours is evident from [Chaucer](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Geoffrey-Chaucer)'s description: Well could he guess the ascending of the star Wherein his patient's fortunes settled were. He knew the course of every malady, Were it of cold or heat or moist or dry. Medieval physicians analyzed symptoms, examined excreta, and made their [diagnoses](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/diagnoses). Then they might prescribe diet, rest, sleep, exercise, or baths, or they could administer emetics and purgatives or bleed the patient. Surgeons could treat fractures and dislocations, repair [hernias](https://www.britannica.com/science/hernia), and perform amputations and a few other operations. Some of them prescribed opium, mandragora, or alcohol to deaden pain. Childbirth was left to midwives, who relied on folklore and tradition. Great hospitals were established during the Middle Ages by religious foundations, and infirmaries were attached to abbeys, monasteries, priories, and convents. Doctors and nurses in these institutions were members of religious orders and [combined](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/combined) spiritual with physical healing.
